newsitem.title: FRANCE: French shares close down 2.82 percent.
newsitem.headline: French shares close down 2.82 percent.

text.p: French shares closed sharply lower on Tuesday, catching up with two big falls on Wall Street posted while Paris was closed for Good Friday and Easter, brokers said.
The CAC-40 index ended 74.86 points or 2.82 percent lower at 2,581.82 after steadying near the close. It had reached a low of 2,556.15 during the day.
April futures were 87 points lower at 2,571.
The market closed just before the release of the U.S. National Association of Purchasing Managers (NAPM) index for March, which rose to 55 from 53.1.

The biggest loser was Franco-Belgian CLF-Dexia France, down 7.58 percent at 561 francs. Dexia announced a 13.1 percent rise in 1996 net income to 19.4 billion Belgian francs and said it expected a further rise in its 1997 results.
The bank said it had the means for acquisitions but had no candidates in sight. Brokers Cheuvreux de Virieu issued a sell recommendation.
Michelin, up 0.45 percent at 336 francs, was the sole gainer of the blue chip shares after a late recovery.
Chargeurs Intl rose 1.74 pct to 356 francs.
Lyonnaise des Eaux, down 3.65 percent at 554 francs, underperformed the market as analysts said investors were scaling down their expectations of benefits from a possible merger with Cie de Suez.
Suez was 1.72 percent lower at 285.9 francs ahead of the publication of its 1996 results.
Suez and Lyonnaise said on Friday they were in merger talks and would make a proposal to special board meetings on April 11.

Saint-Gobain, which has more than six percent in Suez, said it wanted Suez to make a special payment of 10 percent of its financial assets, which it put at 34 billion francs, to shareholders. This would be 22 francs per Suez share.
Saint-Gobain closed down 4.93 percent at 810 francs amid price worries after a profit warning by rival Pilkington Plc of Britain last week.
Saint-Gobain chairman Jean-Louis Beffa said European glass prices would take time to recover.
